title: A Supreme Court Ruling May Make It Harder for Government Agencies to Use Good Science
summary: The Supreme Court is considering weakening Chevron deference, a legal principle allowing courts to defer to agencies' interpretations of ambiguous laws. This could significantly impact how agencies like the FDA and EPA regulate various sectors, potentially slowing down medication approvals and making it harder for them to address issues like climate change. The court's decision will likely lead to more lawsuits challenging agency actions, making it more difficult for them to act effectively on scientific evidence and potentially hampering their ability to protect public health.

title: How the Recycling Symbol Duped People into Buying More Plastic
summary: The article explores the history of the ubiquitous recycling symbol, tracing its evolution from a symbol of hope to a source of confusion and frustration.  While the symbol has played a crucial role in promoting recycling, its widespread adoption on products that are not readily recyclable has created a misleading perception of progress toward sustainability.  The article argues for a shift away from a focus on recycling towards more effective solutions such as reducing consumption and developing reusable products.

greenwashing: The article highlights greenwashing practices associated with the recycling symbol, where companies falsely claim recyclability for products that are not readily recyclable.

title: Inside the Industry Push to Label Your Yogurt Cup ‘Recyclable’
summary: How2Recycle, a third-party organization that labels products as recyclable, has been criticized for claiming that polypropylene, a common type of plastic, is widely recyclable, even though industry experts and environmental advocates say it is rarely recycled. This misleading labeling may be considered greenwashing as it misrepresents the recyclability of polypropylene products, leading consumers to believe they are more environmentally friendly than they actually are.

greenwashing: The How2Recycle labeling system for polypropylene products is considered greenwashing because it misleads consumers by suggesting that these products are widely recyclable when they are not, promoting a perception of environmental friendliness that is not accurate.

title: TCL introduces smart home energy solutions to make clean energy more accessible
summary: TCL PV Technology has launched new n-type TOPCon PV modules featuring highly efficient cells, low degradation rates, and advanced communication systems. These modules are integrated into TCL's Smart Home Energy Solution, which optimizes energy usage, reduces waste, and provides peak-valley arbitrage capabilities. TCL's partnership with BNP Paribas aims to provide homeowners with tailor-made solutions, ensuring cost-effective offerings and reliable services.
product_or_process: n-type TOPCon PV modules and TCL Smart Home Energy Solution

title: Jolly Green Giants: The 7 Best ESG Stocks to Buy Now
summary: This article argues that ESG (environmental, social, and governance) investments are not only morally responsible but also financially sound. It highlights seven companies (Microsoft, Mastercard, Caterpillar, Bunge, Mondelez, Marriott, and Clean Harbors) with strong ESG initiatives and strong financial performance. These companies showcase that prioritizing sustainability can be both ethical and profitable.

title: Enviri Corporation Hosts 2024 Analyst Day in Philadelphia
summary: Enviri, a global environmental solutions provider, is hosting an Analyst Day to discuss its financial performance and outlook. The company is targeting mid-single digit revenue growth and 10-12 percent adjusted EBITDA growth over the next three years, driven by strong market positions and sustainability goals of its customers. Enviri also plans to continue deleveraging its balance sheet, aiming for a credit agreement leverage ratio of 2.5x by 2027.
